Award.AwardTitle: QMHP - Numerical Optimization of Molecular and Nano-Scale Structures for Nonlinear-Optical Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to use general numerical simulation and quantum-mechanical
modeling to guide the development of new paradigms for making materials with an ever-larger nonlinearoptical
response that can apply to a broad range of technologies. The approach is to study how to
optimize the response of individual molecules, determine how to combine molecules into particles to
achieve optimized synergism, study arrangements of particles that yield a bulk material with enhanced
properties, and generate ideas for optimizing material structures to make them most suitable for specific
applications.
Intellectual Merit: This research focuses on building a fundamental understanding of how to control
light?s interaction with matter with the goal of defining guidelines for making improved materials for a
broad range of applications. In addition to contributing to the fundamental Physics of nonlinear optics,
the results will guide chemists in processing and synthesizing new materials; will provide novel
paradigms for physicists/materials scientists for making complex structures; and will give engineers a
broad pallet of systems that impact many applications.
Broader Impact: This work will train undergraduate and graduate students to be the next generation
of interdisciplinary researchers at the cutting edge of science and technology that could, by the breadth of
potential applications, have a large positive impact on the economy. The theoretical techniques are
general, and are appropriate to any applications that are based on light-matter interaction. Potential spinoff
applications include medical imaging/diagnostics, novel cancer therapies, three-dimensional
photolithography, high-density memories, ultra-fast internet switches, and new computer architectures.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The interaction of light with materials is a fundamental process that is the basis of a broad range of applications.  For example, the interaction of electricity with semiconductors is the basis of the transistor, a device that is found in most of today's high-tech gizmos.  Replacing wires with optical fibers and semiconductors with nonlinear-optical materials could enable the next generation of applications in which light replaces electricity, leading to smarter computers, perhaps even machines that think.  Other applications would include new imaging technologies that are applied to medical imaging as well as optically-based cancer therapies.  All of these applications require materials with large "optical nonlinearities" that have yet to be made.

 

This project used general numerical simulation techniques to guide the development of new paradigms for making materials with an ever-larger nonlinear-optical response that is broadly useful to many applications.  We studied how to design the properties of a single molecule to enhance its effectiveness in interacting with light, and developed general principles that have been used by chemists to make better materials.  In addition to guiding the synthesis of new materials, our work has shown how molecules can be placed near each other to enhance their collective response relative to their individual strengths.  Also, our work is providing design criteria to make new materials based on nanowires, in which tightly confined electrons can be manipulated by adding kinks to the wire.

 

The conceptual tools that we have developed will provide novel paradigms for making new and  complex artificial materials that are targeted for specific applications.  Perhaps more importantly, the work is broadening the scientific foundations that will undoubtedly lead to applications that go beyond what can be imagined today.  Potential spin-off applications include medical imaging/diagnostics, novel cancer therapies, three-dimensional photolithography, high-density memories, ultra-fast internet switches, and new computer architectures.
